<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/lumber-prices-hit-alltime-high?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Got Wood?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/lumber-prices-hit-alltime-high" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="An illustration of the wooden frame of a house in front of a lavender background. In front of the house is a red sign with four $ printed on it." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NzQ0L2x1bWJlcl9wcmljZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, lumber futures hit $1,260 per thousand board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. If that sounds like a lot, well, it is—an all-time high.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Lumber prices <a href="https://fortune.com/2021/04/13/lumber-prices-2021-chart-price-of-lumber-futures-short-squeeze-home-sales-cost-april-2021-latest-update/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">have soared</a> during the pandemic. Last April, that same order would've cost just $358.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you think this doesn't affect you...you probably haven't been house hunting recently. Astronomical lumber prices have added $24,000 to the cost of a typical single-family home and $9,000 per apartment, according to the National Association of Home Builders.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What's going on?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1. The pandemic.</strong> At its outset, Covid forced many mills to temporarily close. When historically low mortgage rates met a summer wave of homebuying, renovations, and DIY-ing, producers were unprepared for the demand surge. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Lumber prices kept rising during the winter months, so homebuilders and lumber yards delayed their purchases, hoping prices would come down. Now, with the busy spring/summer building season ahead, homebuilders and lumber yards are rushing to get coveted boards, driving prices even higher.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2. The plague.</strong> Not the human one. Since the 1990s, warmer winters have caused mountain beetles to <a href="https://qz.com/1985276/america-is-running-short-of-wood/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">spread further</a> across British Columbia, infecting more forests. Their arboreal appetites have diminished harvests. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Somewhat ironically, in Europe, a </span><span><em>different</em></span><span> beetle plague is also getting worse and forcing loggers to cut down infected trees before the wood becomes unusable. As the US looks for more supply, Europe has extra to export.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">3. </strong><strong style="color:#000">Labor. </strong>Mills could theoretically produce more...except some are facing labor shortages. While the job can include lots of Vitamin D and flannel, low pay and the difficult, sometimes dangerous work required has pinched manpower.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> The number of homes for sale continues to sit near a record low. While that should be a dream for construction businesses, rising prices and tight inventories for lumber and other building materials have made it more expensive for builders and, in turn, created an affordability crisis for buyers. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
C-SUITE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/jeff-bezos-pens-final-shareholder-letter-ceo-amazon?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Bezos Is too Good at Goodbyes
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/jeff-bezos-pens-final-shareholder-letter-ceo-amazon" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Jeff Bezos smiling " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzYvamVmZl9iZXpvc19zbWlsaW5nLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>picture alliance/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos wrote his first letter to shareholders, the year was 1997, the company was doing $148 million in annual revenue, and an "important" strategic partnership with America Online was just inked. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In his <a href="https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/company-news/2020-letter-to-shareholders?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">final letter</a> before he steps down as CEO, published yesterday, Bezos noted $45 billion in revenue for Amazon Web Services alone, 200 million Amazon Prime members, and 1.3 million employees globally. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And reflections on those employees accounted for most of what Bezos wrote. He discussed the recent union vote in Bessemer, AL, which Amazon defeated but that nonetheless drew national attention to employees' frustrations with working conditions. Bezos admitted, "We need a better <em>vision</em> for how we create value for employees—a vision for their success." </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Amazon is the second-largest private employer in the US behind Walmart. It hired 500,000 people just last year as the pandemic juiced demand for online shopping.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Parting thoughts: </strong>If there was one thing Bezos wanted to get across in this letter, it's to embrace what makes you, you. He wrote, "The world wants you to be typical–in a thousand ways, it pulls at you. Don't let it happen."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/company-news/2020-letter-to-shareholders?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Read the entire letter</a>.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENVIRONMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/googles-new-feature-timelapse-offers-users-view-last-four-decades?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Watch Earth Go Back to the Future
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/googles-new-feature-timelapse-offers-users-view-last-four-decades" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Timelapse of effects from mining in Wright, Wyoming" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=378 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/HvDRW8Dpi30dsckqQI/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Timelapse of effects from mining in Wright, Wyoming" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/HvDRW8Dpi30dsckqQI/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Google Earth Timelapse shows effects of mining in Wright, Wyoming</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you weren't stressed enough about climate change, Google Earth just <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/15/tech/google-earth-timelapse/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> its latest feature, Timelapse, to really make you sweat. With over 24 million satellite photos compiled into an <a href="https://earth.google.com/web/@0,0,0a,22251752.77375655d,35y,0h,0t,0r?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">interactive 4D experience</a>, it's one of the clearest visuals yet of how our planet has changed over the past four decades. Users can toggle from the devastation from Australian wildfires to the rapid growth of San Francisco on the same screen.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google didn't create it just to hurt you. The company <a href="https://www.axios.com/google-earth-timelapse-show-climate-change-deforestation-bd9dced5-8438-4283-bdea-c1ca269c7a4c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wanted to build</a> a tool for governments, researchers, journalists, and teachers to witness the "rapid environmental change in the past half-century."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How it came to be:</strong> Google partnered with organizations including NASA and the US Geological Survey's Landsat program to collect images from 1984–2020 of every location on Earth—yes, even Nebraska. Google said the project took 2 million processing hours across thousands of machines, but stuck to its green commitment and used 100% renewable energy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Easily accessible collections of clear satellite images might be the strongest tool in the fight against climate change.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If time is money, then <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N709945.3407870MORNINGBREW/B25054957.296864202;dc_trk_aid=489913499;dc_trk_cid=128365408;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Heineken 0.0</a> is the gold standard of beverages that you can (and should) enjoy while doing, well, pretty much anything. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Charles Schwab <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/15/retail-trading-boom-schwab-first-quarter-2021-earnings.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">added</a> more clients in Q1 of 2021 (3.2 million) than in all of 2020. Why? Greater interest in high-growth tech companies and meme stocks, said the CEO. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: "</strong>We are grateful for all feedback."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Maybe. <th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/mercedesbenz-reveals-first-electric-sedan?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Benz Has Gone Electric
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/15/mercedesbenz-reveals-first-electric-sedan" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="The Mercedes-Benz 2022 Luxury electric sedan EQS" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/bkJgNKL2rRBPEuoDsj/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="The Mercedes-Benz 2022 Luxury electric sedan EQS" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/bkJgNKL2rRBPEuoDsj/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mercedes-Benz</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a win for cool dads everywhere, Mercedes-Benz <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/4/15/22385437/mercedes-benz-eqs-electric-ev-photos-specs?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a> its new 2022 EQS luxury electric sedan yesterday. The model is scheduled to hit car dealerships in the fall and represents the first of nine electric vehicles the German auto brand plans to release within the year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The EQS can get an impressive 478 miles of range by European standards, but that number is expected to go down when it's tested in the US. There's a chance it could still beat out Tesla’s longest-range Model S, but we'll leave I-80 to settle that debate. Other features include:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A 56-inch “</span><span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/7/22217267/mercedes-benz-hyperscreen-size-specs-eqs-ces-2021?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Hyperscreen</a></span><span>” dashboard consisting of three different screens for passengers to watch </span><span><em>Justice League</em></span><span> the way Zach Snyder intended.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Automatic doors.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Hot stone seat massagers.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out.</strong> Its two-tone paint job is cool, but the most interesting part of the EQS is what it means for other legacy car companies trying to transition away from combustion engines. If EVs are the future of driving, luxury brands need to get it in gear.</p>

BREW'S BETS

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This guy’s up 27,521% on Netflix</strong>. It’s David Gardner, one of the founders of <a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/sa-earlybird?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=sar-earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210172&psource=esamnbwdg0210172&wsource=esamnbwdg0210172" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Motley Fool</a>. Now he’s issued a “Buy Alert” for a recent IPO stock. So, yeah, you may want to listen. In front of the house is a red sign with four $ printed on it.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NzQ0L2x1bWJlcl9wcmljZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, lumber futures hit $1,260 per thousand board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. If that sounds like a lot, well, it is—an all-time high.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLumber prices \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2021/04/13/lumber-prices-2021-chart-price-of-lumber-futures-short-squeeze-home-sales-cost-april-2021-latest-update/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehave soared\u003c/a\u003e during the pandemic. Last April, that same order would've cost just $358.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you think this doesn't affect you...you probably haven't been house hunting recently. Astronomical lumber prices have added $24,000 to the cost of a typical single-family home and $9,000 per apartment, according to the National Association of Home Builders.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat's going on?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1. The pandemic.\u003c/strong\u003e At its outset, Covid forced many mills to temporarily close. When historically low mortgage rates met a summer wave of homebuying, renovations, and DIY-ing, producers were unprepared for the demand surge. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLumber prices kept rising during the winter months, so homebuilders and lumber yards delayed their purchases, hoping prices would come down. Now, with the busy spring/summer building season ahead, homebuilders and lumber yards are rushing to get coveted boards, driving prices even higher.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2. The plague.\u003c/strong\u003e Not the human one. Since the 1990s, warmer winters have caused mountain beetles to \u003ca href=\"https://qz.com/1985276/america-is-running-short-of-wood/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003espread further\u003c/a\u003e across British Columbia, infecting more forests. Their arboreal appetites have diminished harvests. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSomewhat ironically, in Europe, a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003edifferent\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e beetle plague is also getting worse and forcing loggers to cut down infected trees before the wood becomes unusable. As the US looks for more supply, Europe has extra to export.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e3. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLabor. \u003c/strong\u003eMills could theoretically produce more...except some are facing labor shortages. While the job can include lots of Vitamin D and flannel, low pay and the difficult, sometimes dangerous work required has pinched manpower.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e The number of homes for sale continues to sit near a record low. While that should be a dream for construction businesses, rising prices and tight inventories for lumber and other building materials have made it more expensive for builders and, in turn, created an affordability crisis for buyers. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos wrote his first letter to shareholders, the year was 1997, the company was doing $148 million in annual revenue, and an \"important\" strategic partnership with America Online was just inked. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn his \u003ca href=\"https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/company-news/2020-letter-to-shareholders?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efinal letter\u003c/a\u003e before he steps down as CEO, published yesterday, Bezos noted $45 billion in revenue for Amazon Web Services alone, 200 million Amazon Prime members, and 1.3 million employees globally. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd reflections on those employees accounted for most of what Bezos wrote. He discussed the recent union vote in Bessemer, AL, which Amazon defeated but that nonetheless drew national attention to employees' frustrations with working conditions. Bezos admitted, \"We need a better \u003cem\u003evision\u003c/em\u003e for how we create value for employees—a vision for their success.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAmazon is the second-largest private employer in the US behind Walmart. It hired 500,000 people just last year as the pandemic juiced demand for online shopping.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eParting thoughts: \u003c/strong\u003eIf there was one thing Bezos wanted to get across in this letter, it's to embrace what makes you, you. He wrote, \"The world wants you to be typical–in a thousand ways, it pulls at you. Don't let it happen.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/company-news/2020-letter-to-shareholders?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid effects of mining in Wright, Wyoming\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you weren't stressed enough about climate change, Google Earth just \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/15/tech/google-earth-timelapse/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased\u003c/a\u003e its latest feature, Timelapse, to really make you sweat. With over 24 million satellite photos compiled into an \u003ca href=\"https://earth.google.com/web/@0,0,0a,22251752.77375655d,35y,0h,0t,0r?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einteractive 4D experience\u003c/a\u003e, it's one of the clearest visuals yet of how our planet has changed over the past four decades. Users can toggle from the devastation from Australian wildfires to the rapid growth of San Francisco on the same screen.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoogle didn't create it just to hurt you. The company \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/google-earth-timelapse-show-climate-change-deforestation-bd9dced5-8438-4283-bdea-c1ca269c7a4c.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewanted to build\u003c/a\u003e a tool for governments, researchers, journalists, and teachers to witness the \"rapid environmental change in the past half-century.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow it came to be:\u003c/strong\u003e Google partnered with organizations including NASA and the US Geological Survey's Landsat program to collect images from 1984–2020 of every location on Earth—yes, even Nebraska. Google said the project took 2 million processing hours across thousands of machines, but stuck to its green commitment and used 100% renewable energy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eEasily accessible collections of clear satellite images might be the strongest tool in the fight against climate change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" The model is scheduled to hit car dealerships in the fall and represents the first of nine electric vehicles the German auto brand plans to release within the year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe EQS can get an impressive 478 miles of range by European standards, but that number is expected to go down when it's tested in the US. Other features include:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eA 56-inch “\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/7/22217267/mercedes-benz-hyperscreen-size-specs-eqs-ces-2021?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eHyperscreen\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e” dashboard consisting of three different screens for passengers to watch \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eJustice League\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the way Zach Snyder intended.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAutomatic doors.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHot stone seat massagers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out.\u003c/strong\u003e Its two-tone paint job is cool, but the most interesting part of the EQS is what it means for other legacy car companies trying to transition away from combustion engines.
